Title: the plimpton stimulation

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. There is a knock on the door.
The cafeteria. Raj drinks from a hip flask.
Sheldon: Hold.
Explain your sneeze.
Do you have allergies?
Is there too much pepper on your salad?
I’ve heard enough. Sit over there.
That’s what Typhoid Mary said, and clearly, her friends buckled.
Oh, Leonard, I have something for you. Per our roommate agreement, this is your 24-hour notice that I will be having a non-related female spending two nights in our apartment.
Of course. Pets are banned under the roommate agreement, with the exception of service animals, such as seeing eye dogs and, one day, cybernetically-enhanced helper monkeys.
Sarcasm?
For your information, I’ll be playing host to Dr. Elizabeth Plimpton.

Yes. And until you acquire a surgical mask, please address your comments to me through a napkin. We’ve been corresponding for years about our mutual interest in gravitational wave signatures of inflatons in the early universe. And now she’s under consideration for a position at our university.
I didn’t realize I was obligated to share my connection with things you’re a fan of, but very well. You enjoy Canadian bacon. I’ve been to Toronto.
My room, of course.
Go ahead.
A, I rarely kid. And B, when I do kid, you will know it by my use of the word bazinga.
Yes. Bazinga. Leonard?

Well, she doesn’t care for hotels. And who can blame her? Windows that don’t open, multi-user linens, keys shaped like credit cards, as if one walks around with unassigned slots in one’s wallet. All right, I believe I have time for one more question. Yes, Raj?
When I’ve seen two consecutive negative throat cultures spaced 12 hours apart. You know the drill. All right, if you’ll excuse me, I am off to start a prophylactic course of antibiotics.
Oh, Penny, excellent. I have a question about these maxi pads. Are the wings truly functional or have I fallen victim to marketing hype?
The stock boy at Walgreens was frustratingly uninformed on the subject.
I have a lady friend who will be staying with me for a few days.
I want her to feel at home. I also bought scented soaps, pantyhose, Midol, calcium chews and what is apparently a yogurt specifically designed to regulate the female bowel.
Yes. Why does that seem to flabbergast everybody?
A word of warning. My guest is a noted physicist and the leading expert on quantum cosmology, so please try to avoid wasting her time with female jibber jabber.
Shoe sales, hair styles, mud masks, gossip about your friends Brad and Angelina.
I’m not surprised, considering the way you talk about them behind their backs.

Oh, good grief. This isn’t about you. Coming! Now listen, one of the great minds of the 21st century is about to play host to one of the other great minds of the 21st century. So pay attention. Years from now, my biographer might ask you about this event.
Hello.
I would imagine it is. This is my friend and roommate, Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.
I apologize. He’s only an experimental physicist.
No, she’s my guest. If anyone should offer her anything, it should be me. Elizabeth, can I get you something? Perhaps a feminine hygiene product or a bowel-regulating yogurt?
Excellent. If the yogurt works, I bought some delightful scented candles.
No, he doesn’t understand. I understand.
You’re just misappropriating my understanding.
From the mind that brought you hi-lo. Let me show you to your room.
Get it together, man.

All right, let me show you some of the features of the room. First, windows. Conventional. Open, closed, open, closed, halfway open, or halfway closed, depending on your philosophical bent. Over here is my comic book collection. Feel free to browse. There’s a box of disposable reading gloves on the night stand.
Then there’s really no reason to live, is there?
He’s an odd duck, isn’t he?

Well, there was a misbegotten adventure with a waitress who lives across the hall. It ended as inexplicably as it began. They had very little in common, except for carnal activity. That’s why I acquired these noise-cancelling headphones. If you decide to use them, please clean the ear pieces afterwards with the Wet Wipes you’ll find in the bathroom. They’re in the drawer labelled Wet Wipes.

Good. I’ll leave you to your night time ablutions. I’ve e-mailed you the morning bathroom schedule. You’ll also find a laminated copy in your welcome packet. It’s on the back of the emergency escape route diagram.
Sleep well, my friend.
Oh, let me just get one thing. It’s my backup emergency supply kit. The living room escape route doesn’t pass through here. Now, good night. And if there’s an apocalypse, good luck.
Vocal test. Morning vocal test. Second vocal test. Second morning vocal test.
Morning.
Morning. I trust you had a pleasant night.
Excuse me, I’m going to relieve myself.
All right, Elizabeth, the bathroom is yours. The seat is down, and has been sanitized for your protection.
Ah, so the yogurt didn’t work. I’ll fire off a critical e-mail to the manufacturer.
Did you once again ignore your check engine light?
Leonard, Penny wants to exploit any residual feelings you have for her in order to get a ride to work.
Wonderful. Meaningless pleasantries accomplished. Elizabeth, Leonard’s bathroom time is coming up, and believe me, you do not want to follow him.
Excuse me. I’m uncomfortable with you recommending that Leonard pursue having intercourse with Dr. Plimpton, who I assure you has better things to do.
That’s preposterous. Tell her, Leonard.
No.
The implication being that you somehow tripped and fell into her lady parts?
I must say, I’m shocked by this betrayal.
Not Penny, me!
Elizabeth’s my friend, and you’re playing with her!
Dr. Plimpton, I’d like you to meet my colleagues, Dr. Rajesh Koothrappali
And not-a-doctor Howard Wolowitz.
And of course, you’ve already introduced yourself to Dr. Hofstadter.
Raj: What?
I’m sorry?
No.
I don’t put pepper on salads.
Oh, come on. I don’t want to sit by myself.
Guys, help me.
The cosmological physicist from Princeton?
Holy crap! (Through napkin) Holy crap!
When can I sit with you again?
I can’t believe they let him into Canada.
Relax, it’s Nyquil.
Maybe, but I don’t care. That’s the great thing about Nyquil, it’s like ten-percent booze. I call it the nighttime sniffling, sneezing, coughing, so you can talk to girls medicine.
Did you get a cold, too?
She won’t notice they’re missing?
Ooh, ooh. Did the pigeon on your windowsill have more babies?
Did you get a Japanese love pillow?
It is if you love her and give her a name.
Hi.
I’m a big fan of your work.
What?
I can’t. I’m too sick. Go away.
I’m not hungry.
I bought a parrot.
Go away. She wants New Delhi, not Kosher deli. Besides, you have a girlfriend.
Why didn’t you say anything?
Oh, this is like a nightmare. Get lost!
Good?
Okay, show of hands. Who’s up for this? (Only Howard raises his hand.)
Follow my lead. Almost. We’re, we’re going to go out into the hallway and, uh, make a dramatic entrance.
Run. Run, run, run. Don’t look back.
Howard: Sheldon, come on.
See you, buddy.
Are you planning on kidnapping a woman?
Yes, but mixed with genuine concern.
Yeah, um, I have a two-part question.
A, are you kidding me? And B, seriously, are you freaking kidding me?
So you’re saying the two of you are going to be sleeping in the same bed?
Whoa, whoa, whoa. You heard the man. Where’s your throat cultures? Kidding. Sit down.
What the hell are you doing?
If you want, I can give you some of my mom’s sleeping pills.
She doesn’t know she takes them.
Were you up making another stop-motion Lego movie?
‘Cause let me tell you, it’s not enough to make the Legos move, they also have to capture your heart.
How is a Japanese love pillow another person?
Hi.
What do you mean what? It’s Halo night.
That’s why we moved Halo night here. Look, I brought my mom’s chicken soup.
Who’s that
Yeah, right. Dr. Plimpton?
Uh, yeah.
Yeah, sure. In fact, I’m a dungeon master.
Beg pardon?
What the frak?
We broke up weeks ago.
I was waiting for the right time. This is the right time.
He’s right. The numbers are shaky enough as it is.
Yep. Welcome to the Penthouse Forum.
I’m out.
Leonard: Yeah, it’s just one sneeze. (Raj sneezes) You’re on your own.
When you say non-related female, you still mean human, right?
Why didn’t you tell me you knew Elizabeth Plimpton? I am a huge fan of hers!
Okay, fine. Where is she going to sleep?
Thank you. Why is a world-renowned scientist staying in our apartment instead of a hotel?
I can’t believe he’s friends with Elizabeth Plimpton.
She’s here, she’s here. How do I look? Do I look smart?
Oh, I have so many things to tell your biographer.
Hi-lo. Oops. I started to say hi, and then I switched to hello in the middle. It came out hi-lo. Duh. Uh, it’s nice to meet you. I’ve read both your books and most of your papers. I’m Leonard, I live
Are you hungry, thirsty? Can I offer you anything?
Look, it’s you.
Well, who wants to stay in a hotel? With windows that don’t open, those crazy card-shaped keys.
Well, I understand, too.
Oh, (blows a raspberry). I think any university would want you. Except, of course, any university that had already had you. Because they would’ve already wanted you before they, you know, got you.
Uh, sleep night. I mean, obviously, good night. I started to say sleep tight, then I changed my mind in the middle. I swear to God, I’m smart.
Yes?
Is everything all right?
Me neither. Oh, look what I’m reading. It’s you.
I did, but it’s been a while, and I wanted to sound smart over breakfast.
Oh, good. Wasn’t sure it was coming across.
Uh, six.
Sure.
Really? Uh, sure doesn’t read that way.
Wow. You really make science come alive.
Morning, Sheldon.
How do you take your coffee?
Okeydoke.
Something his mother taught him.
Oh, yeah, sure, let me just put this in a travel mug.
Okay, well, I guess I should get dressed so I can take everyone to work. You and Sheldon and Sheldon’s friend, Dr. Plimpton, who you just met. It’ll be fun. Like a clown car.
Hmm? Yeah? What? Huh?
What, uh, you and me? Yeah, we did. Not too long ago. How are you doing with it?
I, um, I don’t follow.
Well, now…
Well…
Come on. It wasn’t my fault.
Penny, I can still drive you.
I didn’t betray Penny.
How am I betraying you?
Yeah, I guess I did.
You still have a cold?
Are you having trouble sleeping? ‘Cause, boy, I was up all night.
No, but I was awake all night.
No, that’s okay. It was something else keeping me up last night. And again this morning. And, I didn’t mind. I was up last night. I was up this morning. I didn’t mind. Those are your clues.
No.
No.
Okay, I’ll give you one more clue. It involved another person.
Hey, you.
Boy, I’m kind of tuckered out. How are you feeling, Elizabeth?
Sure. Black, right?
Coming right up.
Hey, who’s ready for Halo?
I don’t understand.
Elizabeth? What’s going on?
Is she suggesting what I think she’s suggesting?
We’ll all be naked in front of each other.
I thought we had something special.
Hey.
Thanks. It’s really hard to find these in his size. So, listen. I’ve been meaning to talk to you about the other morning.
Yeah, I wanted to explain.
I don’t?
So you’re not judging me?
Nevertheless, I’d like to get one on the record so you can understand why I did what I did.
She let me.
Penny: Hey, Sheldon.
What? What are you doing with, what?
Sheldon, what are you doing with maxi pads?
Oh. What?
Wait, wait, hold on, back up. You’re having a woman stay with you?
Oh, no, no, no, no. I’m not flabbergasted. I’m puzzled. Yeah, let’s go with puzzled.
Female jibber jabber?
Oh, they’re not my friends.
Oh, good, you’re up. Look, my car won’t start. I need a ride to work.
No, Mr. smarty-pants. I ignored the fill gas tank light.
Hello.
Oh, Penny, this is Dr. Plimpton, a leading expert on quantum cosmology. Dr. Plimpton, Penny is a waitress who doesn’t understand the role gasoline plays in the internal combustion engine.
Nice to meet you, too. Are you enjoying your stay?
Good.
Hang on.
We just broke up.
Not as good as you apparently.
You know what? It’s, it’s none of my business. If you want to sleep with Sheldon’s doctor buddy right after we stopped seeing each other, go for it.
I’m not recommending it. I’m saying it already happened.
You know what? I’m just gonna take the bus to work.
Oh, no, no, it’s okay. You might slip on a banana peel and get me pregnant.
Oh, Leonard?
I found these in the dryer. I’m assuming they belong to Sheldon.
You mean you and Dr. Slutbunny?
Well, you don’t owe me an explanation.
No, you don’t.
Oh, I’m judging you nine ways to Sunday, but you don’t owe me an explanation.
I’m listening.
Elizabeth: Ah, Dr. Cooper, thank goodness. I completely forgot your address. But then I remembered that I’d written it on my hand. Lucky for me, I didn’t confuse it with what I’d written on my other hand, which are the coordinates for a newly discovered neutron star. ‘Cause if I tried to go there, I’d be crushed by hypergravity. Anyway, hello.
Nice to finally meet you in person.

No need to apologize. Some of my best friends are experimental physicists. Well, not my best friends, but I know them. My best friend is a molecular chemist named Wendy. I’m sorry, I’m rambling. Hi-lo.
Interesting choices. Based on my current needs, I guess I’d pick the yogurt.
Thank you so much for opening up your home to me.
All right. I guess I am tired. Good night, Leonard.
What if there’s a disaster that destroys all the USB ports?
Can I ask a question about your roommate?
I thought you already read it.
Oh, the extragalactic distance ladder. Want to know a little secret?
I wrote the section on the Wilson-Bappu Effect completely naked.
Here, let me show you. When we consider the brightness of pulsating variable stars, we start to see (removes robe) a possible explanation for some of the discrepancies found in Hubble’s constant.
That’s very thoughtful, but I think I’ll finish my coffee first.
You know what? I am a little tired. Would you be a dear and get me a cup of coffee?
Actually, now I think I want it hot, brown and sweet.
Don’t send him away. Let him in.
Can I ask you a question, Howard? Do you like role-playing games?
Not tonight. Tonight you are a delivery man. You brought soup, but uh-oh, Raj and I don’t have enough money to pay you. So we’ll have to come to some other kind of arrangement.
You two figure out the details, I’m going to go change into something I don’t mind getting ripped off my milky flesh.
What’s going on is you and Howard are my moving men and Raj is my new landlord and I don’t have enough money to pay any of you.
Oh, good. It’s so much better when everyone commits.
Sheldon: In here, you\u2019ll find emerg: The Original Series on a high-density flash drive.
Sheldon (in bathroom): Pee for Houston, pee for Austin, pee for the state my heart got lost in. And shake twice for Texas.
Raj (locks door): So, you say you can’t pay your rent?
